message: if your features get pulled in, you can then merge from upstream
so other than a rather involved rebase -i, is there a way to "remove" a branch from mashup?
I'm thinking of a pattern, but its nascent and wonder if there is something out there better or more developed
the idea is this, you fork a project on github that you want to use
you do that several times, adding >1 feature
you want to be able to contribute back, so you branch to a feature branch, add feature, submit pull

now you want to *USE* that project with all the features you've added so you:

git co -b mashup
git merge feature-1
git merge feature-2
git merge feature-n
of course, this assumes that upstream may be slow to pull, or in fact reject your features
You should be able to use a filter-branch with some magic in a commit filter to target commits which are only reachable from the victim branch. That'd beg to be a well-tested script…
